text: Howdy folks! We're encountering problems when moving our custom modules into the new IDE and we are now working out what to change to make the transition working. Is there a log / documentation / anything about what has been deprecated with this transition? What things used to work before and won't work in the new setting? An example we found by trial and error is `parent_custom_widget_name`
I only managed to find this <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/modules/reference>
Is there anything more than that?
I'm not sure it's a full list, but it may be worth checking out this doc <@U7VDLFJL8> - <https://designers.HubSpot.com/transitioning-from-v1-to-v2-modules>
Thanks... I was checking that myself but I'd better give it a better second read :slightly_smiling_face:

Morning everyone! The page editor team has made some changes under the hood (and a little to the UI) of flex columns and we're looking for some folks to test it out and provide feedback if anything feels unnatural/broken. This is going to be a first step toward a larger change in the page editor, so if  you're interested in getting early access to those features as well, you'll be at the top of the list!
If you are interested in trying these new changes out, please ping me your Hub ID

my response is - *how beta are we talking?* that sounds like a pretty huge feature - I’m excited to see what you guys have been doing, but nervous it could cause some issues if used on a production site
Good question. We've done pretty heavy internal testing and everything seems solid, but you will be among the first people outside of HubSpot to try this feature out.
Well then HubID enroute
<@U22PU4G4A> pinned a message to this channel.
One point of clarification: the changes made are in the front end of the page editor (website pages and landing pages) when you go into Layout Mode
Let me get this to the point of releasing it and we can figure that out!
Is there any update about submission guidelines for modules yet and when the submission period will open to add new modules to the marketplace?

Hey <@U2H3TT8F2>, timely question...

<!here> We've just published our marketplace requirements for module submissions. You can view those here <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/resources/what-are-the-module-requirements-for-the-marketplace>. We'll begin to accept submissions within the next few weeks, but wanted to give you these guidelines in advance!
Thanks <@U87NGNETZ>! This is great!
<@U87NGNETZ> what about HubDB? Is this allowed with Modules?
It doesnt state this in the requirements but I want to make sure
Last time i checked hubdb was not allowed <@U2H3TT8F2>
why only 5 free modules?
I’m getting nit picky but I’d like elaboration on “not compatible with all major web browsers” generally my team supports IE 10 and up. I want to know what is the perceived cut off
Yes, it is allowed. We will be utilizing all parts of the new module framework.
That is reasonable. Any older version of IE is difficult to support.
Will the module simply not show up for users who do not have HubDB on their portal?
Want to make sure we dont run into a "I bought this and it doesnt work cause I dont have HubDB" scenarios

Correct. We are still working through verbiage around this in the submission process. Assets using HubDB will only be available to customers with the websites add-on. This includes Landing Page/ Blog templates that contain a HubDB module.
Any way to NOT automatically include published blog posts in the sitemaps?
just spent 15 minutes selecting every single post and removing
(the client wants NOTHING visible to search engines)

I'm also wondering... Am I able to put a blog into "stealth mode" for lack of a better term... one in which it's basically "off" until it's ready to be live (or in this use case... live and be turned "off" until another time)
Why not add wildcard to robots.txt?
Everything is robots.txt is removed from sitemaps
cool, I didn't know this one

<@U4RP6AGV9> Additionally, not having a page in sitemaps does not guarantee a search engine will not index/display it in search results. The only way to guarantee this is to have it in robots.txt or add a header to the blog template: <https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/93710?hl=en>
here's what I have in robots.txt:

User-agent: AdsBot-Google 
Disallow:
User-agent: Googlebot
Disallow:
User-agent: *
Disallow: /
and I have <meta name="robots" content="noindex"> on all headers
Including a second "just in case" in the template itself + in the header for the templates
somehow it's slipping through anyway (guess some bots just disregard the index rules)
Which page is still being indexed?
We are going to walk before we run with modules in the Marketplace. We could increase in the future, time will tell.

kinda figured after I asked that maybe your plan was to limit it so people don’t create hundreds of low quality modules. limiting it forces people to concentrate on 5 - hopefully meaning better quality ones. Especially if they’re using their free ones to attract new business
When I read the rule about “module and creator must be law abiding, and not morally offensive” my first thought was “danm, no yo mama joke generator huh?”
hahaha. You got it, we are on the same page
I like to add a noindex option at the template level so I don't have to drop the code in to the header each time.
in <#C9LPMCT35|site-search-feedback> there’s an ongoing discussion about adding it to the page editor itself
Actually I was wrong about this, thought they were
feature wish list!
That'd be cool but it's pretty simple to add to the template at the top so it's just one of the modules. then you can offer all sorts of custom things..
For example, we have, on many of our templates, an override for FB images because sometimes FB doesn't know what image to pull so you can force it with a little bit of fancy code.
It there a reason we cant upload anything or create a folder into the template section under ftp?
I think it's to prevent people from copying one paid template into multiple portals, ie an agency purchasing a template for use on multiple client sites.
Yeah but then what is the point of FTP?
I can see you blocking a specific folder but not creating new ones
Not saying it's right, I just think that's the justification lol. I agree.
FTP is only good for editing files. They database needs to know what to do with those files and FTP doesn't always communicate it.
FTP came about because developers wanted it not because HubSpot wanted it.
We mainly used FTP because the File Manager experience was subpar and wanted more of a desktop experience. We never used it for actual templates.
speaking of sitemaps, is there a way to search the sitemap and be able to filter for pages or posts? it would be nice to do a search and only look at the page results.
